Facing protests and outcry over the name in 1995, Cleveland issued a press release that referred to Sockalexis as the true source of the name.
According to Joe Posnanski, a sportswriter for NBC Sports, the Indians name was chosen by sportswriters from the four city newspaper at the request of then-team owner Charles Somers. Posnanski writes they chose the name because the Boston Braves had a dynamite season the year before and it was “a glorious opportunity for…Native American jokes and race-specific clichés and insults that fit well in headlines.”
Posnanski wrote there was never any mention of Sockalexis.
Chris Sockalexis said his family has always stood against the Chief Wahoo logo.
“I guess first and foremost they should lose the logo,” he said. “Indians is still a stereotypical name, but it’s better than Redskins (the Washington NFL football team), so I’m not totally offended by the name Indians, just the logo.”
When he started playing, Louise Sockalexis was called a “wonder” by former New York Giants manager John Ward, who had seen him play in college, according to the Society for American Baseball Research. In his first 20 major league games Sockalexis hit with an average of .372, according to the society.
Sockalexis also faced racial taunts from fans during games.
It's time for the Indians and Redskins to each find another name and mascot--unless they want to sell themselves to majority native American ownership, perhaps.

My dad, a California schoolteacher, had a variable annuity. After he died in 2009, I tried to help my mom cash out of it. The company dragged its heels and we watched the value plunge for months while we waited. After the drop, they finally sent her what little was left.

Teaching is stressful and demands enormous energy. My dad lost weight throughout the school year and it was everything my mom could do to get him to gain it back during the short summer break. Teachers should not be penalized for serving the public by having lousy retirement programs foisted on them.

In statistical reporting, averages are too simplistic.  The average is the sum of the salaries divided by the total population of teachers, that permits skewing as extremely smaller or higher salaries are giving more weighing in arriving at the end result.   A more appropriate sum to use is that of the median. The median is the middle value of the entire salary range of the teaching population and represents a truer picture of compensation as it depicts a typical level of compensation earned by the teaching professionals.
Finland seems to respect teachers.  And let's not forget their trade secret:  give the math formula to the student on a regular part of teaching how to do the problem.  Repitition does work.

I think you are missing the point.  Supporting Trump is only the latest evidence that evangelical Christianity has moved so far from the teachings of Jesus that I am not sure it should be considered Christian at all.  As a Christian, my concern is that the political evangelical movement is succeeding quite well in pushing real Christianity out of the United States much as the Catholic church's failure to stand up to Fascism caused the demise of Christianity in Europe.  Americans who come from a Christian background but who believe in the Constitution and humanistic traditions that have made the United States such a great nation, are rejecting their own religious tradition because they are uncomfortable being associated with a religion that has been so closely tied to the Republican party and all of its evils.

Nicholas, you write: "It is too often acceptable on liberal campuses to create a climate hostile and contemptuous of evangelicals — and that, too, is bigotry".

That hostility you see is not likely due to bigotry, defined as intolerance toward those who hold different opinions from oneself, but contempt for flaming hypocrisy, ie. claiming to be "pro-life" when in fact you are merely pro-birth (once a child is born it is more often than not, considered an onerous burden on society). Just one example of many that come quickly to mind.

How many of those who feel hostility towards evangelicals feel any hostility towards the Amish, even though that demographic might be as far or even more removed from their belief systems as evangelicals.

That would be because the Amish live their religion quietly amongst themselves and do not foist their beliefs on the secular world. They apparently don't bash anyone for what they must certainly see as 'sins' because clearly those sins don't affect their personal relationship to God. Just the way it should be.

The world—as far as I can tell—respects them and leaves them to worship as they wish. There are no doubt isolated exceptions to this but not many.

Evangelicals could benefit from the humility and honesty of the Amish. Respect is earned by giving it sincerely, not demanding it with empty sanctity like so many of the utterly phony evangelicals who regularly make a great show of their twisted interpretations of Christianity.

It would be interesting to give both Hillary and Donald a little Bible quiz, just some basic facts, to see which one of them even knows what the Bible says, much less practices it. I read in the Reader's Digest that Hillary reads the Bible regularly and is strongly influenced by her Methodist faith.  I think it's obvious that Trump's faith starts and ends in himself. But for evangelicals, they have somehow bought into the idea that abortion (which is never mentioned in the Bible at all) is the only issue that matters.

To paraphrase Winston Churchill:
Hillary is the worst candidate for president...except for all the others.

She is fortunate to have a opponent who is not only totally unqualified to be President but who is a racist, a demagogue, and a sexual predator who has appealed to the basest instincts of the American people and ran a campaign of bigotry, intolerance, hate, insults, and mean spiritedness.

Ms. Clinton feels she was owed the nomination and the Presidency, and that she is the most qualified woman in a nation of 330 people to be President. I beg to differ.

I am voting for Hillary Clinton not because I want to but because I have to.

This seems to be the year the Conservatives pundits (as well as the Trump campaign) have chosen to paint "the elites" as the boogymen.

What in the world do they mean by that? People who actually know something? Even if you take away all the nastiness of Trump's campaign, what is left is someone who has absolutely no clue what he is talking about. Just look at any of his "policy" speeches, even the ones on teleprompter, and you are confronted with pure gibberish. Is that the alternative to "the elites" which Douthat would have us entrust the future of the US and the world to?

His "policy speech" this morning about what he "pledges" to do in the first 100 days, at least the part before he got back into his personal grievances, was one of the few speeches which actually sounded like a sane political campaign speech. But even here, on closer inspection, the "policies" don't add up.

His "senior advisors" - Steve Bannon, Roger Ailes and the once respectable, but now virtually demented Giuliani, are about as far away from being "policy elite" as one can get. Are these the kind of people that Douthat would entrust out future to?

The true "policy elites" with whom everyone is fed up are the members of the GOP in Congress who eight years ago declared as their highest objective to "make Obama fail". To that end they have shut down the government twice, threatened to do it several more times, and have voted some 60 off times to repeal ObamaCare.
Don't forget Ailes and Rove; Trump's abettors and enablers.

Dear Dr. Harrison,

My friends who are PhD chemists, and I know several, point out that reducing an alkaline aqueous solution from pH 8.2 to 8.1 or even 7.5 does not make the solution "more acid", because the solution remains alkaline.

Therefore "ocean acidification", although admittedly widely used by the climate alarmist camp, is not correct.

It is a scare tactic used to panic laymen. It is a shameful example of unscientific terminology chosen to advance a preferred policy option.

Do you really think there is "the possibility that the ocean pH could be driven below 7.0 if the CO2 partial pressure goes high enough"?

I challenge you to share with us your calculations on just what that CO2 partial pressure would be, how much hydrocarbons would have to be burned to get to pH 7.0, where we would get that much hydrocarbons, and how long it would take at the rates of hydrocarbon consumption projected for the foreseeable future.

According to the NOAA, the answer is that ocean pH will NEVER go below 7.0.

Can you demonstrate that the NOAA is wrong?
I'm a lifelong Giants fan who has had the thrill of seeing my team win the Series. The Cubs are a great ball club and I hope they go all the way this year!

An immense relief.  1969 was tragic, 2003 was more than tragic.  Even Bartman is smiling.  Only wish my father was still alive to see it.  World series tickets will be ridiculously expensive but it does not matter - I will be there.  Click those heels one last time Ronnie.

I am a fan of the White Sox, but I have to congratulate the Cubs.  They are by far the best team in the National League in 2016, and 71 years from a pennant and 108 years from a championship is too long for any team.  I wish them well in the WS and I look forward to seeing what the White Sox will do this off season to get back the Series and maybe have a Crosstown Classic.
